title: Zero to One
subtitle: Notes on Startups, or How to Build the Future
author: Peter Thiel
review: This book introduced me to the world of tech startups and has probably had the biggest impact on me as a person. Superficially a book of business advice, what it’s actually about is philosophy – specifically how to think critically, dream big and do exceptional work.

title: The Bed of Procrustes
subtitle: Philosophical and Practical Aphorisms
author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
review: This little book of aphorisms is a distillation of Nassim Taleb’s Incerto series and his philosophy in general. For me, Taleb works better in aphorisms than in his longer-form work. Lots of East Med wisdom in here.

title: Finite and Infinite Games
subtitle: A Vision of Life as Play and Possibility
author: James P. Carse
review: This book blew my mind. Though, the way that it’s written is certainly not for everyone. It’s light on technical game theory, and more so provides a way of thinking. “A finite game is played for the purpose of winning, an infinite game for the purpose of continuing the play.”

title: Gödel, Escher, Bach
subtitle: An Eternal Golden Braid
author: Douglas R. Hofstadter
review: An amazing, trippy adventure. Don’t go into this one with the goal of trying to learn something from it. You might learn a lot, but that’s not the point. The point is to hang out with Douglas Hofstadter and see what intellectual pathway he’ll take you down next. It’s almost like a nonfiction Alice in Wonderland.

title: The Machiavellians
subtitle: Defenders of Freedom
author: James Burnham
review: I learned more about political science from this book than anywhere else. Burnham walks through the ideas of several thinkers in the Machiavellian school – including Machiavelli himself – and their efforts to study politics in an objective, scientifically rigorous way, free of ideology.

title: Bronze Age Mindset
author: Bronze Age Pervert
review: I started reading this as a joke, but what I found was a surprisingly wholesome work of philosophy that resonated with me deeply. A mondern restatement of Nietzsche, if you will. Though not without its own original ideas - the concept of 'owned space' is one that I think about a lot, for example.

title: Unqualified Reservations: Vol. 1
author: Mencius Moldbug
review: Curtis is one of my favorite writers – he has a unique voice and is a deep systems thinker. This is a collection of some of his most popular writings on unqualified-reservations.org, delving into an analysis of our current political system from a Machiavellian perspective (see: Burnham, The Machiavellians). If for nothing else, UR is an intellectual adventure to places way beyond the Overton window.

title: The Captive Mind
author: Czesław Miłosz
review: A first-hand account of the Soviet ideological capture of the Polish poetry scene. Essential reading.

title: Notes from Underground
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
review: Left me depressed for a week. Maybe one day I'll summon the courage to reread it. 10/10.

title: The Road to Reality
subtitle: A Complete Guide to the Laws of the Universe
author: Roger Penrose
review: I’m still making my way through this – essentially, this is a technical yet somewhat casual walk through the core ideas in modern physics. Penrose’s passion for physics is incredibly infectious.

title: Visual Complex Analysis
author: Tristan Needham
review: Still reading this one. What I will say is that this is one of the best textbooks I’ve ever read. Needham’s writing is extremely clear, passionate and conversational. And as the title suggests, there’s a visual explanation for the concepts presented wherever possible. This goes a long way to help bootstrap mental models.

title: The Prince / Discourses on Livy
author: Niccolò Machiavelli
review: Machiavelli is the Newton of political science, as far as I'm concerned. Very few are able to analyze political systems with the clarity and scientific detachment needed to make any real sense of it. Machiavelli perhaps does it best.

title: Dieter Rams: Less But Better
author: Dieter Rams
review: Dieter Rams is a huge inspiration, and has greatly informed my aesthetic taste. This book is a collection of his work, and a great introduction to his philosophy of design. Minimalism almost misses the point - it's not about keeping things minimal, rather about keeping only the essential. No design choice should be made without purpose.

title: Apple Human Interface Guidelines (1987)
author: Apple Computer Inc.
review: A wonderful treasure trove of early Apple design philosophy. There's a freshness to it that's hard to find in modern design writing.
